sense.name: the act of shoving something away
sense.examples: He closed the door with a push. The fight between the boys began with pushes and shoves.

sense.name: a propulsive force, thrust
sense.examples: The energy from the burning fuel gives the rocket the push it needs to reach escape velocity. Unequal push from the plane's two engines made it veer off course.

sense.name: being ambitious or enterprising
sense.examples: He's an investor with the necessary money and push to succeed. Many co-workers view her push as shameless self promotion.

sense.name: the act of pressing a button, an electronic switch
sense.examples: The elevator button may need another push to activate it. Frantic pushes of the doorbell woke John up from a deep sleep.

sense.name: making an effort to advance a goal
sense.examples: The army was engaged in a push against guerilla strongholds. There is a push on now to spend the budget before year's end. It was a huge push, but Mary completed her thesis in time to graduate this year.

sense.name: an impetus, or influence on something
sense.commentary: PUSH[+relation][+role][+influential][+impetus] Note: metaphoric extension of Sense 1 that refers to situations, settings
sense.examples: Her career was given a push by the success of her last film. Johnny needed a push from his parents to buckle down and study.

sense.name: IDIOM: a decisive moment
sense.examples: When push comes to shove, people look out for their own needs. They will probably back down when push comes to shove.
